subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] dictionary, script not working
msgSnippet: ... There was no norm worth mentioning: just look at a transcription of the First Folio and you can see how much variation there actually was. In casual
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> I know that Shakespeare spelled the same words different ways,
> but I'm thinking that his spellings didn't vary much from the norm.

There was no norm worth mentioning: just look at a transcription of
the First Folio and you can see how much variation there actually was.
In casual writing, it's even worse: Shakespeare spelled his name a
dozen ways ("Shakespeare" not being one of them), of which my favorite
is "Shagspur".

> Put another way, if a QS writer wants to spell a word different than
> standard pronounciation, then he should be aware he is doing so.

Alas, standard pronunciation is something English doesn't have.

--
What is the sound of Perl? Is it not the John Cowan
sound of a [Ww]all that people have stopped cowan@...
banging their head against? --Larry http://www.ccil.org/~cowan

Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> I know that Shakespeare spelled the same words different ways, 
> but I'm thinking that his spellings didn't vary much from the norm.

There was no norm worth mentioning: just look at a transcription of 
the First Folio and you can see how much variation there actually was.
In casual writing, it's even worse: Shakespeare spelled his name a
dozen ways ("Shakespeare" not being one of them), of which my favorite
is "Shagspur".

> Put another way, if a QS writer wants to spell a word different than 
> standard pronounciation, then he should be aware he is doing so.

Alas, standard pronunciation is something English doesn't have.
